item.title: Choose your own adventure: researcher degrees of freedom and questionable research practices in ecological modelling for decision support
item.author: elise.gould@unimelb.edu.au (Elise Gould)
item.description: Abstract: Initial meta-science research in ecology and evolution suggests that the discipline is not immune to the sorts of reproducibility issues highlighted in other scientific disciplines, such as Psychology and Medicine. A recent study has revealed rates of self-reported Questionable Reserach Practices (QRPs) in ecology and evolution comprable to other disciplines. QRPs include practices such as cherry-picking, p-hacking and hypothesising after results are known (HARKing), and result in low rates of reproducibility, contributing to biased accounts of the subject domain in the body of literature.
